â
'''Google, Inc.''' ({{nasdaq|GOOG}}) is a [[United States|U.S.]] [[public corporation]], initially established as a [[privately held corporation]] in [[1998]], which designed and currently manages the Internet [[Google search]] engine. Google's corporate headquarters is at the "[[Googleplex]]" in [[Mountain View, Santa Clara County, California|Mountain View]], [[California]] and employs almost 5,000 employees. [[Eric E. Schmidt|Dr. Eric Schmidt]], former [[CEO]] of [[Novell]], was named the Chief Executive Officer when co-founder [[Lawrence E. Page|Larry Page]] stepped down. The company's overview web page states that "Google's mission is to organize the world's information and make it universally accessible and useful."
+
'''Google, Inc.''' ({{nasdaq|GOOG}}) is a [[United States|U.S.]] [[public corporation]], first established as a [[privately held corporation]] in [[1998]], that designed and manages the Internet [[Google search]] engine. The firm, which employs nearly 5,000, has corporate headquarters at the "[[Googleplex]]" in [[Mountain View, Santa Clara County, California|Mountain View]], [[California]]. The company mission is "to organize the world's information and make it universally accessible and useful."[http://www.google.com/intl/en/corporate/index.html] [[Eric E. Schmidt|Eric Schmidt]], formerly [[chief executive officer]] of [[Novell]], was named Google's CEO when co-founder [[Lawrence E. Page|Larry Page]] stepped down.
==History==
==History==
===Beginnings===
===Beginnings===
[[Image:Google.com front page.png|thumb|right|300px|Google.com front page]]
[[Image:Google.com front page.png|thumb|right|300px|Google.com front page]]
â
Google began as a research project in January [[1996]] <sup>[http://www.google.com/intl/en/corporate/history.html]</sup> by [[Lawrence E. Page|Larry Page]] and [[Sergey Brin]], two [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] students at [[Stanford University|Stanford]]. They developed the hypothesis that a search engine based on analysis of the relationships between Web sites would produce improved results over the basic techniques then in use. (At the time, other search engines ranked results essentially based on how many times the search term appeared on a page.) It was originally nicknamed ''BackRub'' because the system checked [[backlinks]] to estimate a site's importance. (A small search engine called [[RankDex]] was already exploring a similar strategy.)
+
Google began as a research project in January [[1996]] <sup>[http://www.google.com/intl/en/corporate/history.html]</sup> by Page and [[Sergey Brin]], two [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] students at [[Stanford University|Stanford]]. They hypothesized that a search engine that analyzed the relationships between Web sites would produce better results than existing techniques. (Contemporary search engines essentially ranked results according to how many times the search term appeared on a page.) It was originally nicknamed ''BackRub'' because the system checked [[backlinks]] to estimate a site's importance. (A small search engine called [[RankDex]] was already exploring a similar strategy.)
Convinced that the pages with the most links to them from other highly relevant Web pages must be the most relevant pages associated with the search, Page and Brin tested their thesis as part of their studies, and laid the foundation for their search engine. Originally the search engine used the [[Stanford University|Stanford]] website with the domain ''google.stanford.edu'' (see the [http://www.archive.org/web/web.php Internet Archive Wayback Machine] search for [http://web.archive.org/web/*/http://google.stanford.edu http://google.stanford.edu]). The domain ''google.com'' was registered on [[September 15]], [[1997]]. They formally incorporated their company, ''Google Inc.'', on [[September 7]], [[1998]] at a friend's garage in [[Menlo Park, California]].
Convinced that the pages with the most links to them from other highly relevant Web pages must be the most relevant pages associated with the search, Page and Brin tested their thesis as part of their studies, and laid the foundation for their search engine. Originally the search engine used the [[Stanford University|Stanford]] website with the domain ''google.stanford.edu'' (see the [http://www.archive.org/web/web.php Internet Archive Wayback Machine] search for [http://web.archive.org/web/*/http://google.stanford.edu http://google.stanford.edu]). The domain ''google.com'' was registered on [[September 15]], [[1997]]. They formally incorporated their company, ''Google Inc.'', on [[September 7]], [[1998]] at a friend's garage in [[Menlo Park, California]].
